alternate the colours during knitting as often as you like - for more consistent and clean stripes always change to a new colour on the same side of your work at the start of the row - remember to leave a long enough tail of yarn for weaving in the ends later on - for randomly changing stripes simply change the colour at any point of your process here you can use for example the magic knot technique to minimize weaving in the ends later on knitting pattern by milena pauliina milena juhola ©copyright @milenapauliina 4 2023 this pattern is for personal use only the pattern is not to #badgerset be copied sold or redistributed neither is the sale of garments made from this pattern allowed your notes badger scarf my tips start by deciding the length and width-style for your scarf ordinarily a skinnier scarf is also slightly shorter whereas a wider more regular scarf is slightly longer feel free to use my sample measurements below or measure an existing scarf that you like for reference skinny scarf example 140 cm 55 in long 9 cm 3 5 in wide regular scarf example 178 cm 70 in long 15 cm 6 in wide when you have decided on the length multiply that with the 1 cm stitch gauge you calculated earlier example you want your scarf to be 140 cm long 140 x 2 5 = 350 if you end up with a decimal round this number to the nearest full number you will need to cast on 350 stitches for your scarf to make it approximately 140 cm long you now have your measurements and you are ready to start knitting leave a tail on yarn in the length you want the fringes to be recommended minimum 7 cm 2 75 in and cast on the required number of stitches for the length using the crochet cast on method work back and forth in garter stitch as follows *pull the yarn in a loop in the length of the fringe k to end of row* repeat from * to * on every row tie little knots to the roots of the fringes as you go to secure them and keep the edge of the scarf nice and tidy once you have made the knots you can cut the loops open for
